column3: You'll probably have a good many more and worse disappointments than that before you get through life, said Marilla, who honestly thought she was making a comforting speech.

column2: It seems to me, Anne, that you are never going to outgrow your fashion of setting your heart so on things and then crashing down into despair because you don't get them.
column3: It seems to me, Anne, that you are never going to outgrow your fashion of setting your heart so on things and then crashing down into despair because you don't get them.

column2: I know I'm too much inclined that, way agreed Anne ruefully.
column3: I know I'm too much inclined that, way agreed Anne ruefully.

column2: When I think something nice is going to happen I seem to fly right up on the wings of anticipation; and then the first thing I realize I drop down to earth with a thud.	When I think something nice is going to happen I seem to fly right up on the wings of anticipation; and then the first thing I realize I drop down to earth with a thud.
column3: true

column2: But really, Marilla, the flying part IS glorious as long as it lasts . . . it's like soaring through a sunset.
column3: But really, Marilla, the flying part IS glorious as long as it lasts . . . it's like soaring through a sunset.

column2: I think it almost pays for the thud."
column3: I think it almost pays for the thud."

column2: Well, maybe it does, admitted Marilla.
column3: Well, maybe it does, admitted Marilla.

column2: I'd rather walk calmly along and do without both flying and thud.	I'd rather walk calmly along and do without both flying and thud.
column3: true

column2: But everybody has her own way of living . . .
column3: But everybody has her own way of living . . .

column2: I used to think there was only one right way . . . but since I've had you and the twins to bring up I don't feel so sure of it.
column3: I used to think there was only one right way . . . but since I've had you and the twins to bring up I don't feel so sure of it.

column2: What are you going to do about Miss Barry's platter?"
column3: What are you going to do about Miss Barry's platter?"

column2: Pay her back the twenty dollars she paid for it, I suppose.	Pay her back the twenty dollars she paid for it, I suppose.
column3: true

column2: I'm so thankful it wasn't a cherished heirloom because then no money could replace it."
column3: I'm so thankful it wasn't a cherished heirloom because then no money could replace it."

column2: Maybe you could find one like it somewhere and buy it for her.
column3: Maybe you could find one like it somewhere and buy it for her.

column2: I'm afraid not.	I'm afraid not.
column3: true

column2: Platters as old as that are very scarce.
column3: Platters as old as that are very scarce.

column2: Mrs. Lynde couldn't find one anywhere for the supper.
column3: mrs Lynde couldn't find one anywhere for the supper.

column2: I only wish I could, for of course Miss Barry would just as soon have one platter as another, if both were equally old and genuine.
column3: I only wish I could, for of course Miss Barry would just as soon have one platter as another, if both were equally old and genuine.

column2: Marilla, look at that big star over Mr. Harrison's maple grove, with all that holy hush of silvery sky about it.
column3: Marilla, look at that big star over mr Harrison's maple grove, with all that holy hush of silvery sky about it.

column2: It gives me a feeling that is like a prayer.
column3: It gives me a feeling that is like a prayer.

column2: After all, when one can see stars and skies like that, little disappointments and accidents can't matter so much, can they?"
column3: After all, when one can see stars and skies like that, little disappointments and accidents can't matter so much, can they?"

column2: Where's Davy? said Marilla, with an indifferent glance at the star.
column3: Where's Davy? said Marilla, with an indifferent glance at the star.

column2: In bed.	In bed.
column3: true

column2: I've promised to take him and Dora to the shore for a picnic tomorrow.
column3: I've promised to take him and Dora to the shore for a picnic tomorrow.

column2: Of course, the original agreement was that he must be good. But he TRIED to be good . . . and I hadn't the heart to disappoint him."
column3: Of course, the original agreement was that he must be good. But he TRIED to be good . . . and I hadn't the heart to disappoint him."

column2: You'll drown yourself or the twins, rowing about the pond in that flat, grumbled Marilla.
column3: You'll drown yourself or the twins, rowing about the pond in that flat, grumbled Marilla.

column2: I've lived here for sixty years and I've never been on the pond yet.
column3: I've lived here for sixty years and I've never been on the pond yet.

column2: Well, it's never too late to mend, said Anne roguishly.
column3: Well, it's never too late to mend, said Anne roguishly.

column2: Suppose you come with us tomorrow.	Suppose you come with us tomorrow.
column3: true

column2: We'll shut Green Gables up and spend the whole day at the shore, daffing the world aside."
column3: We'll shut Green Gables up and spend the whole day at the shore, daffing the world aside."

column2: No, thank you, said Marilla, with indignant emphasis.
column3: No, thank you, said Marilla, with indignant emphasis.

column2: I'd be a nice sight, wouldn't I, rowing down the pond in a flat?	I'd be a nice sight, wouldn't I, rowing down the pond in a flat?
column3: true

column2: I think I hear Rachel pronouncing on it.
column3: I think I hear Rachel pronouncing on it.

column2: There's Mr. Harrison driving away somewhere.
column3: There's mr Harrison driving away somewhere.

column2: Do you suppose there is any truth in the gossip that Mr. Harrison is going to see Isabella Andrews?"
column3: Do you suppose there is any truth in the gossip that mr Harrison is going to see Isabella Andrews?"

column2: No, I'm sure there isn't.	No, I'm sure there isn't.
column3: true

column2: He just called there one evening on business with Mr. Harmon Andrews and Mrs. Lynde saw him and said she knew he was courting because he had a white collar on.
column3: He just called there one evening on business with mr Harmon Andrews and mrs Lynde saw him and said she knew he was courting because he had a white collar on.

column2: I don't believe Mr. Harrison will ever marry.
column3: I don't believe mr Harrison will ever marry.

column2: He seems to have a prejudice against marriage."
column3: He seems to have a prejudice against marriage."

column2: Well, you can never tell about those old bachelors.	Well, you can never tell about those old bachelors.
column3: true

column2: And if he had a white collar on I'd agree with Rachel that it looks suspicious, for I'm sure he never was seen with one before."
column3: And if he had a white collar on I'd agree with Rachel that it looks suspicious, for I'm sure he never was seen with one before."

column2: I think he only put it on because he wanted to conclude a business deal with Harmon Andrews, said Anne.
column3: I think he only put it on because he wanted to conclude a business deal with Harmon Andrews, said Anne.

column2: I've heard him say that's the only time a man needs to be particular about his appearance, because if he looks prosperous the party of the second part won't be so likely to try to cheat him.	I've heard him say that's the only time a man needs to be particular about his appearance, because if he looks prosperous the party of the second part won't be so likely to try to cheat him.
column3: true

column2: I really feel sorry for Mr. Harrison; I don't believe he feels satisfied with his life.
column3: I really feel sorry for mr Harrison; I don't believe he feels satisfied with his life.

column2: It must be very lonely to have no one to care about except a parrot, don't you think?
column3: It must be very lonely to have no one to care about except a parrot, don't you think?

column2: But I notice Mr. Harrison doesn't like to be pitied.
column3: But I notice mr Harrison doesn't like to be pitied.

column2: Nobody does, I imagine."
column3: Nobody does, I imagine."
